content.text: SSL/TLS (Secure Sockets Layer/Transport Layer Security) encrypts all data transmitted between your website and users' browsers, ensuring that sensitive information like passwords, credit card numbers, and personal data cannot be intercepted by hackers.

Without SSL/TLS encryption, hackers can intercept and steal sensitive information transmitted over the network. This is especially critical for websites handling user authentication, payment processing, or any personal data.

items: TLS version (must be 1.2 or higher for security)
SSL grade (A+, A, B, C, D, F) via SSL Labs API
Keep certificates up to date and renew before expiration
Use strong cipher suites (avoid weak ciphers like RC4, MD5)
Use valid certificates from trusted Certificate Authorities (CAs)
Implement proper certificate pinning for mobile apps

content.title: Expired Certificates
content.text: Certificates that have passed their expiration date will cause browser warnings and may prevent users from accessing your site.

content.title: Weak TLS Versions
content.text: Older TLS versions (1.0, 1.1) have known vulnerabilities and should be disabled. Always use TLS 1.2 or higher.

content.title: Self-Signed Certificates
content.text: Self-signed certificates are not trusted by browsers and will show security warnings to users, reducing trust in your website.

content.title: Mixed Content
content.text: HTTPS pages loading HTTP resources (mixed content) can compromise security and should be avoided.
